channel.dc:title: Chemistry — A European Journal (no repeats)

item.title: Escaping from Flatland: Stereoconvergent Synthesis of 3‐Dimensional Scaffolds via Ruthenium(II)‐Catalyzed Noyori‐Ikariya Transfer Hydrogenation.
item.dc:description: Noyori‐Ikariya‐type ruthenium(II)‐catalysts for asymmetric transfer hydrogenation (ATH) have been known for 25 years and have proved as a well‐behaved and user‐friendly platform for the synthesis of chiral secondary alcohols. A progress has been made in the past five years in understanding the asymmetric reduction of complex ketones, where up to four stereocenters can be controlled in a single chemical transformation. Intriguing multi‐chiral molecular architectures are therefore available in few well understood and robust synthetic steps from commercially available building blocks, and possess handles for additional functionalization. The aim of this review is to showcase the availability of three‐dimensional scaffolds and homo‐chiral lead‐like compounds via ATH and inspire their direct use in drug discovery endeavors. Basic mechanistic insights are provided to demystify the stereo‐chemical outcomes, as well as examples of diastereoselective transformations of enantiopure alcohols to give a feeling of how these rigid non‐planar molecules can be further elaborated.
item.dc:creator: Andrej Emanuel Cotman
item.content:encoded: Noyori‐Ikariya‐type ruthenium(II)‐catalysts for asymmetric transfer hydrogenation (ATH) have been known for 25 years and have proved as a well‐behaved and user‐friendly platform for the synthesis of chiral secondary alcohols. A progress has been made in the past five years in understanding the asymmetric reduction of complex ketones, where up to four stereocenters can be controlled in a single chemical transformation. Intriguing multi‐chiral molecular architectures are therefore available in few well understood and robust synthetic steps from commercially available building blocks, and possess handles for additional functionalization. The aim of this review is to showcase the availability of three‐dimensional scaffolds and homo‐chiral lead‐like compounds via ATH and inspire their direct use in drug discovery endeavors. Basic mechanistic insights are provided to demystify the stereo‐chemical outcomes, as well as examples of diastereoselective transformations of enantiopure alcohols to give a feeling of how these rigid non‐planar molecules can be further elaborated.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Accepted Article.
item.dc:title: Escaping from Flatland: Stereoconvergent Synthesis of 3‐Dimensional Scaffolds via Ruthenium(II)‐Catalyzed Noyori‐Ikariya Transfer Hydrogenation.

item.title: Handling (Nano‐)Silver as Antimicrobial Agent: Therapeutic Window, Dissolution Dynamics, Detection Methods and Molecular Interactions
item.dc:description: Silver is a well‐known antimicrobial agent known since antiquity. With the emergence of multi‐resistant bacteria, it has come back into the focus of research, and ionic as well as nano‐sized silver has been studied in vitro and in vivo. The results are controversial, silver being discussed as the “silver bullet” or a “wolf in sheep’s clothing”. A thorough search of literature from chemistry, materials and environmental science, biology and medicine lead to this review in which we resume the potential use of silver and its compounds in medicine, ongoing processes of dissolution and the different methods by which this usefulness can be evaluated. It also highlights the therapeutic window of silver, mechanistic interactions of silver and biological media as well as best practices for handling silver in a biomedical environment. While still not fully understood, this review reflects the current knowhow and observations, and may thus give hints and guidelines to understand and interpret the observed effects.
item.dc:creator: Sarah-Luise Abram, Katharina M. Fromm
item.content:encoded: Silver is a well‐known antimicrobial agent known since antiquity. With the emergence of multi‐resistant bacteria, it has come back into the focus of research, and ionic as well as nano‐sized silver has been studied in vitro and in vivo. The results are controversial, silver being discussed as the “silver bullet” or a “wolf in sheep’s clothing”. A thorough search of literature from chemistry, materials and environmental science, biology and medicine lead to this review in which we resume the potential use of silver and its compounds in medicine, ongoing processes of dissolution and the different methods by which this usefulness can be evaluated. It also highlights the therapeutic window of silver, mechanistic interactions of silver and biological media as well as best practices for handling silver in a biomedical environment. While still not fully understood, this review reflects the current knowhow and observations, and may thus give hints and guidelines to understand and interpret the observed effects.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Accepted Article.
item.dc:title: Handling (Nano‐)Silver as Antimicrobial Agent: Therapeutic Window, Dissolution Dynamics, Detection Methods and Molecular Interactions

item.title: Frontispiece: All‐Inorganic Single‐Ion Magnets in Ceramic Matrices
item.dc:description: Single‐ion magnets (SIMs) are magnetic compounds that could retain their magnetization after removing the field but due to noninteracting isolated magnetic ions (as it is illustrated by the figure) instead of domains in classical ferromagnets. Usually they are constructed from metal–organic complexes of magnetic d or f ions but here, a Minireview of another approach that is using inorganic solid state compounds as a matrix for individual magnetic ions with SIM properties is presented by M. A. Zykin et al. on page 8834 ff.
item.dc:creator: Mikhail A. Zykin, Pavel E. Kazin, Martin Jansen
item.content:encoded: Single‐ion magnets (SIMs) are magnetic compounds that could retain their magnetization after removing the field but due to noninteracting isolated magnetic ions (as it is illustrated by the figure) instead of domains in classical ferromagnets. Usually they are constructed from metal–organic complexes of magnetic d or f ions but here, a Minireview of another approach that is using inorganic solid state compounds as a matrix for individual magnetic ions with SIM properties is presented by M. A. Zykin et al. on https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.201905290page 8834 ff.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 26, Issue 41, July 22, 2020.
item.dc:title: Frontispiece: All‐Inorganic Single‐Ion Magnets in Ceramic Matrices

item.title: Frontispiece: Nanoporous Metals for Heterogeneous Catalysis: Following the Success of Raney Nickel
item.dc:description: Nanoporous metals (NPMs) have recently attended great interest as heterogenous catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and long‐term stability. They can be readily fabricated by dealloying monolithic alloys through chemical or electrochemical processes. A summary of recent achievements for the use of NMPs as well as a discussion of their active sites and structure–property correlation is given in the Minireview of Y. Gao and Y. Ding on page 8845 ff.
item.dc:creator: Yanxiu Gao, Yi Ding
item.content:encoded: Nanoporous metals (NPMs) have recently attended great interest as heterogenous catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and long‐term stability. They can be readily fabricated by dealloying monolithic alloys through chemical or electrochemical processes. A summary of recent achievements for the use of NMPs as well as a discussion of their active sites and structure–property correlation is given in the Minireview of Y. Gao and Y. Ding on https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.202000471page 8845 ff.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 26, Issue 41, July 22, 2020.
item.dc:title: Frontispiece: Nanoporous Metals for Heterogeneous Catalysis: Following the Success of Raney Nickel

item.title: Frontispiece: Mechanochemical Synthesis of Short DNA Fragments
item.dc:description: A “Mill & Shake” process to make DNA fragments: This study demonstrates that di‐ and trinucleotides can be assembled under ball‐milling conditions by multi‐step reactions, in a one‐pot fashion, and in the absence of bulk solvents. The process is fully compatible with H‐phosphonate and phosphoramidite chemistries, currently applied to oligo‐DNA and RNA synthesis. For more information, see the Communication by M. J. Damha et al. on page 8857 ff.
item.dc:creator: James D. Thorpe, Daniel O'Reilly, Tomislav Friščić, Masad J. Damha
item.content:encoded: A “Mill & Shake” process to make DNA fragments : This study demonstrates that di‐ and trinucleotides can be assembled under ball‐milling conditions by multi‐step reactions, in a one‐pot fashion, and in the absence of bulk solvents. The process is fully compatible with H‐phosphonate and phosphoramidite chemistries, currently applied to oligo‐DNA and RNA synthesis. For more information, see the Communication by M. J. Damha et al. on https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.202001193page 8857 ff.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 26, Issue 41, July 22, 2020.
item.dc:title: Frontispiece: Mechanochemical Synthesis of Short DNA Fragments

item.title: Ratiometric Detection of ATP by Fluorescent Cyclophanes with Bellows‐Type Sensing Mechanism
item.dc:description: The cover feature illustrates the mechanism of ATP detection by a new fluorescent receptor in aqueous solution. The receptor works like bellows: it exists in solution in a stacked form but opens only for binding of ATP. Moreover, the receptor represent an example of a ratiometric probe, which changes its color from yellow to blue upon ATP recognition. Test tubes in the picture display our efforts to separate the pyrene derivatives by column chromatography. More information can be found in the Full Paper by E. A. Kataev et al. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202001523). The cover was designed by Alexander Oshchepkov and authors.
item.dc:creator: Aleksandr M. Agafontsev, Tatiana A. Shumilova, Aleksandr S. Oshchepkov, Frank Hampel, Evgeny A. Kataev
item.content:encoded: The cover feature illustrates the mechanism of ATP detection by a new fluorescent receptor in aqueous solution. The receptor works like bellows: it exists in solution in a stacked form but opens only for binding of ATP. Moreover, the receptor represent an example of a ratiometric probe, which changes its color from yellow to blue upon ATP recognition. Test tubes in the picture display our efforts to separate the pyrene derivatives by column chromatography. More information can be found in the Full Paper by E. A. Kataev et al. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200152310.1002/chem.202001523). The cover was designed by Alexander Oshchepkov and authors.
item.dc:title: Ratiometric Detection of ATP by Fluorescent Cyclophanes with Bellows‐Type Sensing Mechanism

item.title: Highly Efficient Luminescent Solar Concentrators Based on Benzoheterodiazole Dyes with Large Stokes Shifts
item.dc:description: Luminescent solar concentrators (LSCs) are an attractive architectural solution as building‐integrated photovoltaics for renewable electricity production in urban settings, on the way to self‐sufficient housing. When embedded in polymer matrices, bright benzoheterodiazole dyes with large Stokes shifts produce LSCs with state‐of‐the‐art optical and external quantum efficiency. Cover design by Gaia Barbieri. More information can be found in the Full Paper by N. Armaroli, K. Yoosaf, A. Barbieri et al. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202001210).
item.dc:creator: Sheng Gao, Bamisha Balan, Karuvath Yoosaf, Filippo Monti, Elisa Bandini, Andrea Barbieri, Nicola Armaroli
item.content:encoded: Luminescent solar concentrators (LSCs) are an attractive architectural solution as building‐integrated photovoltaics for renewable electricity production in urban settings, on the way to self‐sufficient housing. When embedded in polymer matrices, bright benzoheterodiazole dyes with large Stokes shifts produce LSCs with state‐of‐the‐art optical and external quantum efficiency. Cover design by Gaia Barbieri. More information can be found in the Full Paper by N. Armaroli, K. Yoosaf, A. Barbieri et al. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200121010.1002/chem.202001210).
item.dc:title: Highly Efficient Luminescent Solar Concentrators Based on Benzoheterodiazole Dyes with Large Stokes Shifts

item.title: Thermal Adaptation of Enzymes: Impacts of Conformational Shifts on Catalytic Activation Energy and Optimum Temperature
item.dc:description: Evolution has led to conserved enzyme families that efficiently catalyze the same chemical reaction but in radically different thermal environments. In particular, some enzymes need to be stable and to work in very hot conditions that usually lead to protein melting. Using atomistic simulations and analytic modeling, it is shown that the temperature‐dependence of the enzyme accessible conformations plays a key role in the determination of its optimum working temperature, that cannot be predicted from its melting temperature alone. More information can be found in the Full Paper by D. Laage, F. Sterpone, G. Stirnemann et al. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.2012001973).
item.dc:creator: Irene Maffucci, Damien Laage, Fabio Sterpone, Guillaume Stirnemann
item.content:encoded: Evolution has led to conserved enzyme families that efficiently catalyze the same chemical reaction but in radically different thermal environments. In particular, some enzymes need to be stable and to work in very hot conditions that usually lead to protein melting. Using atomistic simulations and analytic modeling, it is shown that the temperature‐dependence of the enzyme accessible conformations plays a key role in the determination of its optimum working temperature, that cannot be predicted from its melting temperature alone. More information can be found in the Full Paper by D. Laage, F. Sterpone, G. Stirnemann et al. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.201200197310.1002/chem.2012001973).
item.dc:title: Thermal Adaptation of Enzymes: Impacts of Conformational Shifts on Catalytic Activation Energy and Optimum Temperature

item.title: A Systematic Study of Coumarin–Tetrazine Light‐Up Probes for Bioorthogonal Fluorescence Imaging
item.dc:description: Bioorthogonal fluorogenic reagents that produce after chemical activation fluorescent products represent superior probes for cellular imaging. Due to the improved signal‐to‐noise ratio, they can be applied in no‐wash fluorogenic labeling experiments. The present study reveals a set of coumarin‐tetrazine light‐up probes, which produce bright dyes in reaction with TCO or BCN dienophile‐tagged molecules and enable fast bioorthogonal labeling in live cells. More information can be found in the Full Paper by M. Vrabel et al. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202001290).
item.dc:creator: Juraj Galeta, Rastislav Dzijak, Jan Obořil, Martin Dračínský, Milan Vrabel
item.content:encoded: Bioorthogonal fluorogenic reagents that produce after chemical activation fluorescent products represent superior probes for cellular imaging. Due to the improved signal‐to‐noise ratio, they can be applied in no‐wash fluorogenic labeling experiments. The present study reveals a set of coumarin‐tetrazine light‐up probes, which produce bright dyes in reaction with TCO or BCN dienophile‐tagged molecules and enable fast bioorthogonal labeling in live cells. More information can be found in the Full Paper by M. Vrabel et al. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200129010.1002/chem.202001290).
item.dc:title: A Systematic Study of Coumarin–Tetrazine Light‐Up Probes for Bioorthogonal Fluorescence Imaging

item.title: Hexanoate‐Cucurbit[7]uril: Highly Soluble with Controlled Release Ability
item.dc:description: With the presence of the hexanoate group, hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril integrates multiple promising functions for drug delivery. On one hand, hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril inherits the high binding affinity of cucurbit[7]uril with significant increase in solubility; on the other hand, hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril demonstrates controlled cargo release ability under mild acidic condition (cover design: Chen Cheng and Hao Chen). More information can be found in the Communication by H. Chen et al. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202001959).
item.dc:creator: Hao Chen, Jin Zhang, Qun Yu, Yanru Chen, Yebang Tan
item.content:encoded: With the presence of the hexanoate group , hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril integrates multiple promising functions for drug delivery. On one hand, hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril inherits the high binding affinity of cucurbit[7]uril with significant increase in solubility; on the other hand, hexanoate‐cucurbit[7]uril demonstrates controlled cargo release ability under mild acidic condition (cover design: Chen Cheng and Hao Chen). More information can be found in the Communication by H. Chen et al. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200195910.1002/chem.202001959).
item.dc:title: Hexanoate‐Cucurbit[7]uril: Highly Soluble with Controlled Release Ability

item.title: Targeting an Interaction Between Two Disordered Domains by Using a Designed Peptide
item.dc:description:
“We present a new strategy for inhibiting the interaction between disordered domains using a designed peptide, which is derived from combining the disordered parts of an interaction partner and omitting the part with secondary structure. Thus, the “coupled folding and binding” interaction mechanism of the parent peptide was changed in the designed peptide to binding without the need for pre‐folding.” Read more about the story behind the cover in the Cover Profile and about the research itself on page ▪▪ ff. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202000465).
Abstract Invited for the cover of this issue is the group of Assaf Friedler at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. The image depicts the protein–protein interactions reported in this work. Read the full text of the article at 10.1002/chem.202000465.
item.dc:creator: Guy Mayer, Zohar Shpilt, Shachar Bressler, Orly Marcu, Ora Schueler‐Furman, Edit Y. Tshuva, Assaf Friedler
item.content:encoded:
“We present a new strategy for inhibiting the interaction between disordered domains using a designed peptide, which is derived from combining the disordered parts of an interaction partner and omitting the part with secondary structure. Thus, the “coupled folding and binding” interaction mechanism of the parent peptide was changed in the designed peptide to binding without the need for pre‐folding .” Read more about the story behind the cover in the Cover Profile and about the research itself on page ▪▪ ff. (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200046510.1002/chem.202000465).


Abstract

Invited for the cover of this issue is the group of Assaf Friedler at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. The image depicts the protein–protein interactions reported in this work. Read the full text of the article at https://doi.org/10.1002/chem.20200046510.1002/chem.202000465.
item.dc:title: Targeting an Interaction Between Two Disordered Domains by Using a Designed Peptide

item.title: Thermal Elimination of Ethylene from Cyclobutyl Groups Characterized by X‐ray Crystallography in a Metal–Organic Framework Matrix
item.dc:description:
The thermolytic expulsion of ethylene from cyclobutyl rings isolated in a metal–organic framework matrix delivers vinyl‐substituted aromatic compounds that cannot be prepared by conventional synthetic routes.
Abstract Methods to synthesize and characterize aromatic molecules with vinyl substituents are sought after yet limited in the literature. Here, we introduce cyclobutyl groups into a metal–organic framework (MOF) matrix that are poised to produce ethylene upon heating. The expulsion of ethylene produces vinyl groups on an aromatic core, which are isolated by the crystalline matrix of the framework. This enables full characterization of the thermolysis by single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction. Further, we modify the vinyl groups by a bromine addition reaction. Importantly, the two transformations happen in a single‐crystal‐to‐single‐crystal manner without changing the overall network structure of the parent framework. New insights into the structural and synthetic chemistry of this important class of compound are generated. Installing reactive vinyl tags in materials by the high temperature thermolysis of cyclobutyl groups is a powerful strategy for altering their physicochemical characteristics.
item.dc:creator: Adil Alkaş, Laurine E. S. Friche, Shikeale N. Harris, Shane G. Telfer
item.content:encoded:
The thermolytic expulsion of ethylene from cyclobutyl rings isolated in a metal–organic framework matrix delivers vinyl‐substituted aromatic compounds that cannot be prepared by conventional synthetic routes.


Abstract

Methods to synthesize and characterize aromatic molecules with vinyl substituents are sought after yet limited in the literature. Here, we introduce cyclobutyl groups into a metal–organic framework (MOF) matrix that are poised to produce ethylene upon heating. The expulsion of ethylene produces vinyl groups on an aromatic core, which are isolated by the crystalline matrix of the framework. This enables full characterization of the thermolysis by single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction. Further, we modify the vinyl groups by a bromine addition reaction. Importantly, the two transformations happen in a single‐crystal‐to‐single‐crystal manner without changing the overall network structure of the parent framework. New insights into the structural and synthetic chemistry of this important class of compound are generated. Installing reactive vinyl tags in materials by the high temperature thermolysis of cyclobutyl groups is a powerful strategy for altering their physicochemical characteristics.
item.dc:title: Thermal Elimination of Ethylene from Cyclobutyl Groups Characterized by X‐ray Crystallography in a Metal–Organic Framework Matrix
